Cell.Data: text serounded by {} or [] are special tags for code. These tag will be replaced with other text eg: the name of a player. The tags should NOT be localized. They represent the place in the sentens for their replacing string. Some {} tags start with STR or INT. STR means it will be replaced with text, INT means it will be replaced with a numerical value
refering to the player. As in: you have won a battle
as in: this is your colony

A header for a message stating: 'The diplomatic state is already queued, no trade or response has to be made by the opposing player. This happens when breaking out of an alliance/defensive pact or going to war from a non-aggression pact. There is a one turn delay before the state is actually changed so the aggressing player cannot immediately attack.'
You just broke an alliance. You cannot attack your former ally this turn.
massage to the player telling him to wait a turn before attacking his former alliance
You just broke a non-aggression pact. You cannot attack the player you had this pact with this turn.
massage to the player telling him to wait a turn before attacking his former alliance
You are about to break your alliance with {STR_targetPlayer}. Are you sure?
warning message before a player breaks his alliance, which is a diplomatic state/treaty.
You are about to break your defensive pact with {STR_targetPlayer}. Are you sure?
warning message before a player breaks his defensive pact, which is a diplomatic state/treaty.
You are about to break a non-aggression pact with {STR_targetPlayer}. Are you sure?
warning message before a player breaks his peace threaty
You are about to declare war on {STR_targetPlayer}. Are you sure?
warning message before a player declares war on another player

You are about to attack an army belonging to {STR_targetPlayer} that is trespassing in your domain. You are currently not at war with {STR_targetPlayer}, and they will receive 2 [casusBelli/] if you attack them. Are you sure?
warning message before a player goes into combat with a trespassing army - i.e. an army in the players domain - noting the consequences of such an action. This message has a yes/no button under it

The trespassing army belongs to one of your allies, {STR_targetPlayer}. You must break your alliance with {STR_targetPlayer} before you can attack this trespasser in your domain. Are you sure you want to break the alliance?
warning message noting that the player can't attack his allies army, eventhough the army is tresspassing, without breaking his alliance with that player. This message has a yes/no button under it
You currently share a fixed diplomatic state with {STR_targetPlayer} and can therefore not declare war to attack them.

warning message noting that the player can't attack his allies army, eventhough the army is tresspassing. In this case the alliance can't be broken, as it is a fixed alliance set in the game lobby before starting the match
You are about to use an operation on a player you are not at war with. You must declare war on them before being able to target them with this operation.
You are about to use an operation on an NPC faction you are not at war with. You must declare war on them before being able to target them with this operation.
You can only use this operation on players you are at war with. You currently share a fixed diplomatic state with the other player and cannot break that relationship.

Knowledge is used to rediscover and apply the lost technologies of the Star Union. It affects how quickly you research new Society and Military technologies.
description for knowledge - the resource - use
Energy is the main universal currency in the game. It is used for the production and upkeep of units, colony structures, unit modules and operations.

Influence is the diplomatic currency used to manipulate other players and NPC factions. It can be used for things like asking NPCs to move from locations, hiring NPC mercenaries, and making diplomatic pronouncements.
Your reputation determines how other Empires and NPC factions see you. Your Reputation is affected by your in-game actions.

The following hazards are present in this sector:
Are you sure you wish to continue?

You are currently in 'auto-assign colonist' mode. You can switch to and from manual mode by clicking this circle.[br/][br/]In auto-assign colonist mode, colonists will be automatically assigned to a resource. You can change the priority of the resource by clicking the focus button next to that resource.

You are currently in 'manual assign colonist' mode. You can switch to and from auto mode by clicking this circle.[br/][br/]In manual assign colonist mode, you can assign your colonists using the arrow keys associated with each resource.

These colonists are idle. You should assign them to a resource using the arrow buttons associated with each resource. Alternatively, you could switch auto-assign colonist mode on, which will automatically deal with idle colonists.

This number shows the number of rioters in your colony. Rioters occupy a resource slot, but do not generate any income.[br/][br/]Rioters are caused by unhappiness events and hostile operations launched against your colony. To get rid of rioters, ensure that you have a positive happiness income or activate Martial Law in your colony. This will turn rioters back into normal colonists over time.

When Martial Law is enabled, no positive or negative happiness events can occur, and a rioter is converted back into a regular colonist every three [turn/]. [br/]Activating Martial Law has a 25% chance that the rioter is killed instead of converted to a regular colonist.[br/][br/]Under Martial Law, your colony produces 20% less income for all resources.
An infinite number of outcomes lay[br/]between glorious victory and dishonorable defeat.[br/]This time, you live to see another day.[br/]Embrace this new spectrum of possibilities.

You have been defeated.[br/]The remnants of your empire rust[br/]in the vast ruins of the Star Union.[br/]Take heart. Know that every stone you moved[br/]and every word you uttered[br/]will leave an everlasting echo in this cosmic symphony.

Congratulations, Commander.[br/]You stand at the brink of a New Age.[br/]Your diplomacy and hard work have unified the planet.[br/]I confess, I feel a tinge of envy.[br/]It is a difficult balance to maintain.[br/]May you succeed where I failed[br/]and bring about a more perfect Union.

A victor stands proud upon the ruins of their enemies.[br/]You subjugated this world through force,[br/]as the empires of the past did.[br/]When the dust settles,[br/]you will discover whether your cause was just,[br/]or if you merely fanned the flames of entropy.
VO: Empress Carminia Changed 'his' to 'their' to make text gender neutral

While some empires lie in ruin,[br/]we dominate this world under the banners of newly formed alliances, proving that strong diplomatic bonds can be more powerful than the largest of armies. In trust and unity, we march forward to a better tomorrow.

Victory is imagined as a dazzling moment of glory,[br/]the hero slaying the dragon.[br/]In reality, success is the result of a series of small achievements,[br/]slowly outpacing all rivals. Well done, Commander.

Players in a team are in a permanent alliance with players of the same team, while being permanently at war with players of other teams.[br/][br/][warningRed]Enabling teams will disable many diplomatic systems, such as casus belli, changing diplomatic state and insults.[/warningRed]
tooltip for on/off checkbox for the Teams option. Alliance and war are diplomatic in-game terms

Enable/Disable the Score Victory[br/]Score Victory is achieved by having the highest accumulated score at the end of the set turn limit. The score depends on how well you perform in various areas, which can be reviewed in-game.
Select the turn limit for the Score victory
tooltip for the drop-down box the speed for the Score victory. Turn is in-game term
tooltip for each option for above drop-down box. Turn is in-game term. {INT_DURATION} is an insert for the turn limit for each option.

Enable/Disable the Doomsday Victory[br/]Doomsday Victory is achieved by launching a Secret Tech Doomsday operation and defending the required Doomsday structures for a set amount of turns. To reach this, you will have to focus on researching your Secret Tech.
tooltip for on/off checkbox for the Doomsday Victory. Secret Tech is a gameplay term, which means special research.
Select how many turns a player has to defend their Doomsday structures after launching the Doomsday operation
tooltip for drop-down box to select the speed for the Doomsday victory
{INT_DURATION}[turn/] turns after launching the Doomsday operation
tooltip for each option for above drop-down box. Turn is in-game term. Operations is in-game term. {INT_DURATION} is an insert for the turn limit for each option.

Enable/Disable the Unifier Victory[br/]Unifier Victory is achieved by launching the Planetary Unification Protocol and maintaining its requirements for a certain amount of turns (Probation Period). To reach this, you will have to focus on diplomacy to improve NPC faction relations and increase your reputation.

tooltip for on/off checkbox for the Unifier Victory; a special type of victory that requires the player to unify the planet through in-game diplomacy. Probation Period, turn, NPC faction relations and reputation are in-game terms/concepts

Select the following Unifier Victory settings:[br/][bulletList][bullet]How many NPC Dwellings are needed to cast Planetary Unification Protocol[/bullet][bullet]The base turn duration of the Unifier Probation Period[/bullet][bullet]Amount of turns for Final Consideration Mode[/bullet][/bulletList]
tooltip for the drop-down box to change the various settings for the Unifier victory. NPC Dwellings, turns, Probation Period and Final Consideration Mode are in-game terms/concepts

[bulletList][bullet]{INT_AMOUNT} NPC Dwellings needed to cast Planetary Unification Protocol ({INT_LARGEAMOUNT} in Large and Enormous maps)[/bullet][bullet]Probation Period has a base duration of {INT_DURATION}[turn/] turns ({INT_LARGEDURATION} in Large and Enormous maps)[/bullet][bullet]{INT_DURATION_FINAL}[turn/] turns of Final Consideration Mode[/bullet][/bulletList]

tooltip for each option for above drop-down box. {INT_AMOUNT} is an insert for the amount of Dwellings needed. {INT_DURATION} defines the probation period turn limit and {INT_DURATION_FINAL} defines the final consideration mode turn limit. Large and Enormous are choice the playe makes about the size of the game world.

Enable/Disable Domination victory[br/]Domination Victory is achieved by expanding your domain until you own a set amount of sectors and defending them for a certain amount of turns. The amount of sectors needed to trigger the countdown is relative to the map size.
tooltip for on/off checkbox for the Domination Victory. Sectors is an in-game term; essentially areas of land

Select the percentage of the inhabitable sectors needed to trigger the Domination Victory.[br/]When Allied Victory is enabled, the amount of sectors needed is increased depending on how many allies you have.
tooltip for the drop-down box to change the various settings for the Domination victory. Inhabitable in the context of "able to colonize". Sectors is an in-game term
{INT_AMOUNT}% of the total inhabitable sectors needed. ({INT_AMOUNT_ALLY}% with 1 ally, {INT_AMOUNT_ALLIES}% with 2 or more allies)

tooltip for each option for above drop-down box. {INT_AMOUNT} is an insert for the percentage of total land/sectors needed to win. {INT_AMOUNT_ALLY} is the same but when the player has 1 allied player. {INT_AMOUNT_ALLIES} is the same but with 2 or more players.

AI Passivity affects how AI players interact with the player, how often they will send messages, how inclined on starting a war they are and whether they can use covert ops.
The AI is more likely to start wars and has a higher starting dislike towards other players.
tooltip for the AI passivity settings
The AI occassionally sends messages and responds to the player's actions, can always use covert ops and is able to declare war when they want.
tooltip for the AI passivity settings
The AI will interact slightly less and is less inclined to starting wars, they can only use covert ops while at war and have a lower starting dislike towards other players.
tooltip for the AI passivity settings

The AI will still interact but on far fewer occasions, they are far less inclined to start wars, covert ops towards the player has been disabled and their starting dislike towards other players is negligible.

The overall capability represents how players measure up against each other in total, in regards to the three different capability subcategories.
Military capability represents a player's army strength and overall military power, as well as offensive operation capacity.
Unity capability represents a player's performance in creating peaceful resolutions with other players and factions.
Development capability represents a player's research power, as well as colony expansion and development.

When accumulated happiness exceeds one of these numbers, it will generate a negative or positive happiness event

Colonists require happiness to stay productive. Positive happiness can build up to a happiness event, giving your city a boost in resource income.[br/]Unhappiness can lead to an unrest event, which can cause a number of your colonists to stop working.[br/]Your happiness per turn determines whether you are building up to a happiness event or an unrest event, which will trigger when a certain amount of happiness (or unhappiness) has accumulated.

Share up to all of the food surplus with other colonies to meet their demands. All excess will be sold, stopping the growth of the colony and converting it to energy.
Share up to half of the food surplus with other colonies to meet their demands.
Take food shared by other colonies to compensate for food deficits in this colony.

Take food shared by other colonies to accelerate growth in this colony. Food is distributed among all taking colonies equally, but a colony can only take as much food as it would need to get its next colonist.

This allows you to set if you want to have a maximum, minimum or balanced number of [population/] assigned to generate {STR_ResourceIcon} income. Click the button to cycle through the options.

The colony will try to maximize total income, without distinguishing between types of income.[br/]It will assign colonists to the sector that has the highest total income.[br/]When total income is equal it will assign colonist to get a balanced income across all income types.

This assigns the maximum number of colonists to generate {STR_ResourceIcon} income.[br/]Likely to the detriment of other types of income for the colony.[br/]You can maximize more than one type of income, but this might reduce how much you get from both.
Note that the colony will always try to gather enough food to pay for colonist upkeep, and enough happiness to keep the colony happy, unless they are on minimized focus.
Food is used to grow the population of your colonies and keep them alive.
Energy is used as upkeep for your troops and certain buildings, and to launch special operations. It can also be used to buy units or buildings in a pinch.
Production allows you to build units, specialize sectors, and upgrade your colonies.
Happiness is used as an income for the happiness event. Positive happiness leads to a happiness event; negative happiness leads to unrest and riots.

Shown when the player cannot select Martial Law. Martial Law is an option that removes happiness penalties for the colony's colonists but also reduces in their motivation and therefore the colony's income. With this activated, every 3 turns rioting colonists will revert to normal ones.
Martial law can only be activated when there are rioters in this colony.
This represents the relation from the dwelling factor towards the player; how much the player is in favor with them. Building up favor will increase the diplomatic state.
Tooltip for the Favor value shown when in the NPC faction communication interfaces. NPC favor is a gameplay term for the kindness you express towards this NPC faction.

Favor represents the kindness you have expressed towards this NPC faction. It can be increased by completing quests or by trading with dwellings.[br/][br/]Reaching a certain amount of favor will increase your relation state with this faction. Declining demands from this faction will reset the favor to 0 or ,when the favor is already at 0, causes the faction to go to war with you.
Tooltip for when a player selects an unbalanced combination of map size and player amount in advanced settings on RMG.

Warning, the size of the map you have selected combined with the number of players you have chosen can lead to an unbalanced game experience. We recommend adjusting either the map size or the number of players to recommended values.[br/][br/]Recommended are the following:[br/][bulletlist][bullet]Small map (2-6 players)[/bullet][br/][bullet]Medium map (4-8 players)[/bullet][br/][bullet]Large map (6-10 players)[/bullet][br/][bullet]Enormous map (8-12 players)[/bullet][/bulletlist]

As in a summary of the settings for this game. Displayed in multiplayer and when setting up a game using advanced settings.

Displayed next to a button - for players using a controller - to indicate the context sensitive action the button will trigger. Shown in the diplomacy interface, where the player can select another player - human or AI - and then press this button to start negotiations with that player.
Shown in character - i.e. commander - customization. It's the name of a tab under which the player can change the appearance - e.g. looks - of their commander.

Shown in character - i.e. commander - customization. It's the text displayed next to a button, indicating the context sensitive action wired to the button. In this case pressing the button finalizes - i.e. completes - the commander customization process.

A story message is the conversation dialogs which appears in Campaign. The event panel lists all past story message (small button left of minimap). This text will be used as a pre-fix for those past story messages.

Cell.Data: Do you want to continue anyway?
Question asked at the end of a warning. Used in a modal dialog where there will be two buttons to choose from. "Continue" / "Cancel".
A mod refers to user generated content that can be enabled. "Mods" is plural.
This is a title of an error dialog. The error dialog will appear when there is a mismatch in the currently installed mods, versus the mods that the save file was saved with.
You are missing the following mods
Used in the mod conflict error dialog to enumerate the missing mods
The following mods should be disabled
Used in the mod conflict error dialog to enumerate the surplus of mods
You have outdated versions of the following mods
Used in the mod conflict error dialog to enumerate the outdated mods (i.e. mods have versions)
You have an unknown conflict with the following mods
Used in the mod conflict error dialog to enumerate the mods with unknown conflict
Used to indicate the what mod version a save file expects you to have. E.g. Expected version 1.23.512
Used to indicate the what mod version you currently have. E.g. Your version 1.23.512
There is a player online in this session with different mods than you. The mods must match.
Error message when you try to join a multiplayer session when there is already someone in the session with different mods than you.
You have newer mods than those currently in the session. If you continue the session will be upgraded, but may become unstable. Do you want to continue?
Error message when you try and upgrade a multiplayer session. Note: As opposed to the above message (PLAYERS_IN_SESSION) there are no players online in the session.
You are currently using different mods than the game was saved with.
Error message to indicate that the player is loading a singleplayer game that was saved with different (version) mods
If you try and play the game, it may become unstable. Would you like to continue?
Warning message in singleplayer in case player disregards the error message and loads the game anyway.

A 'Combat Retry' is when a player did a combat, and didn't like the results, then the player can press a button called 'Retry'. This will undo the results, and the player can play the same battle again.
Enables the option to retry an auto combat against AI. This makes it possible to get a different outcome if the previous outcome was not desired.
Combat Retry requires a combat card. If a player has no combat card, then retrying is not possible.
Retrying a combat will discard the current results and will start manual combat.
Retrying this combat costs a combat card {STR_Icon}.
Retrying this combat is not possible because all other involved players must be AI players.
Retrying this combat is not possible because you've already fought in manual combat
